results.snippet: The planned launching of the space shuttle Challenger next week has been scrubbed because of problems with two $100 million satellites, space officials announced tonight. Senator Jake Garn, Republican of Utah, had been scheduled to be a passenger...
results.lead_paragraph: The planned launching of the space shuttle Challenger next week has been scrubbed because of problems with two $100 million satellites, space officials announced tonight. Senator Jake Garn, Republican of Utah, had been scheduled to be a passenger on the spaceship. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said it would combine some features of the mission with those of another flight that had been scheduled for March 22. The combined mission, which will require outfitting the shuttle Discovery for a Canadian communications satellite that was to have flown on next week's journey, may not get off the ground until April. Officials could not say whether Senator Garn would be on that flight, but if precedent is followed, he would.

headline.main: REAGAN'S STAR WARS BID: MANY IDEAS CONVERGING

results.snippet: In January 1982, Dr. Edward Teller, a physicist who played a central role in developing the hydrogen bomb, met with President Reagan to discuss new ways of trying to destroy enemy missiles and warheads during an attack.    It was the first of four...
results.lead_paragraph: In January 1982, Dr. Edward Teller, a physicist who played a central role in developing the hydrogen bomb, met with President Reagan to discuss new ways of trying to destroy enemy missiles and warheads during an attack. It was the first of four meetings Dr. Teller would have with the President before the ''Star Wars'' speech of March 23, 1983. In that address Mr. Reagan called on American scientists to find ways of rendering nuclear weapons ''impotent and obsolete.''

results.snippet: Two satellites were removed from the space shuttle Challenger's cargo bay, including a possibly defective one that caused the cancellation of a mission that was scheduled last Thursday.    The suspect payload, a NASA Tracking and Data Relay...
results.lead_paragraph: Two satellites were removed from the space shuttle Challenger's cargo bay, including a possibly defective one that caused the cancellation of a mission that was scheduled last Thursday. The suspect payload, a NASA Tracking and Data Relay Satellite, will have to be modified because it is believed to have a timing problem in a system that encodes communications on Defense Department shuttle missions.

headline.main: THE VERY TIMELY ART OF ROBERT LONGO

results.snippet: ''The most important thing about being an artist is to figure out where you're supposed to be, and who's your audience,'' says Robert Longo. ''Then you sort of catch your time. You have to know and understand the realm of high art and what the...
results.lead_paragraph: ''The most important thing about being an artist is to figure out where you're supposed to be, and who's your audience,'' says Robert Longo. ''Then you sort of catch your time. You have to know and understand the realm of high art and what the boundaries are. Most artists just flounder around and read too many art magazines.'' Cocky, clever, a cultural iconoclast with a sharp nose for the Zeitgeist, Mr. Longo at 32 is one of the most ambitious and versatile animateurs of the present generation. A media-child weaned on television, movies and news magazines, his multichannel skills include drawing, sculpture, performance art, video, film and music (he used to man the guitar in a rock band). His way of catching our ''time'' is by playing back to us the pressures, contradictions and even hopes engendered by its charged mix of cultures - urban, corporate, technological and media - in taut, sometimes powerful icons that he has said ''exist somewhere between movies and monuments.'' Mr. Longo's new installation at the Brooklyn Museum (through May 6) is called ''Temple of Love.'' The six pieces - some older, some especially conceived for the occasion - in this interesting but uneven show trace developments in his work over the last five years, from the early, large-scale black-and-white drawings that first brought him recognition to current three-dimensional ''combines'' of painting, photography and sculptural relief.

results.snippet: The sister of Thomas Creighton, the 33-year- old Arizona auto mechanic who received three hearts, including an unsanctioned artificial heart, in 46 hours last week, said Mr. Creighton would be cremated and his ashes would be saved so they might be...
results.lead_paragraph: The sister of Thomas Creighton, the 33-year- old Arizona auto mechanic who received three hearts, including an unsanctioned artificial heart, in 46 hours last week, said Mr. Creighton would be cremated and his ashes would be saved so they might be launched into space. According to a report in the Arizona Daily Star today, Mr. Creighton's sister, D. Anne, who asked that her last name not be disclosed, said her brother had expressed a wish that his ashes be saved for burial in space.

headline.main: THE LATEST IN LUXURIES: BURIAL IN OUTER SPACE

results.snippet: It used to be that everybody was buried over in Queens.    ''This, gentlemen, is the Space Age,'' Rafael Ross announced to his audience. ''There are thousands of machines in space, and now it is time to put a person up there. Not a machine, but a...
results.lead_paragraph: It used to be that everybody was buried over in Queens. ''This, gentlemen, is the Space Age,'' Rafael Ross announced to his audience. ''There are thousands of machines in space, and now it is time to put a person up there. Not a machine, but a real person. A dead person.''

headline.main: NAVY CHIEF SEES GAIN IN SPACE SHUTTLE FLIGHT

results.snippet: A Navy oceanographer who traveled on a space shuttle flight last fall brought back ''some fantastically important'' information that will make it easier for American submarines to hide in the oceans, the Chief of Naval Operations said today.   ...
results.lead_paragraph: A Navy oceanographer who traveled on a space shuttle flight last fall brought back ''some fantastically important'' information that will make it easier for American submarines to hide in the oceans, the Chief of Naval Operations said today. The Chief, Adm. James D. Watkins, also said the Navy had dramatically increased its emphasis on space and satellites and its appreciation of them.

results.snippet: THE Presidential conferences that Hofstra University has sponsored annually since 1982 are designed to offer scholarly assessments of the careers and programs of the men who held office. They are not, insists Dr.       Paul F. Harper, chairman of...
results.lead_paragraph: THE Presidential conferences that Hofstra University has sponsored annually since 1982 are designed to offer scholarly assessments of the careers and programs of the men who held office. They are not, insists Dr. Paul F. Harper, chairman of the university's political science department, meant to memorialize, celebrate or honor. So when scholars, politicians and journalists gather on the Hempstead campus on Thursday for the fourth conference, ''John F. Kennedy: The Promise Revisited,'' they will come, Dr. Harper said, not merely to praise the New Frontier, but to explore it objectively. ''Of course, we can't avoid some of the commemorative aspects,'' said Dr. Harper, director of the three-day conference. ''Especially, for example, when we bring together members of his staff for a panel discussion. I'm sure that will be filled with reminiscing about the good old days.

headline.main: If Fderalism Is Obsolete, It's Better to Say So

results.snippet: To the Editor:     ''Good Old Federalism'' (editorial, Feb. 21) describes the Supreme Court's recent overruling of League of Cities v. Usery as a ''welcome return to sensible federalism.'' It marks, rather, the end of federalism as a notion with...
results.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Good Old Federalism'' (editorial, Feb. 21) describes the Supreme Court's recent overruling of League of Cities v. Usery as a ''welcome return to sensible federalism.'' It marks, rather, the end of federalism as a notion with any support in the Constitution. The basis for your optimism - and of Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun's majority opinion - is that the values implicit in a Federal system do not need constitutional support because they are amply protected by the political system. That was, in fact, the thesis of an article by Prof. Herbert Wechsler of the Columbia law faculty in 1954 titled ''The Political Safeguards of Federalism: The Role of the States in the Composition and Selection of the National Government.'' But 1985 is not 1954; much has happened since then to erode the political foundations of federalism.

headline.main: REAGAN PRESSES CALL FOR ANTIMISSILE PLAN BEFORE SPACE GROUP

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT

results.snippet: President Reagan today renewed his call for research on a space-based defense against nuclear missiles, invoking a line from the film ''Star Wars'' to rebut critics of the proposal.    ''The Strategic Defense Initiative has been labeled 'Star...
results.lead_paragraph: President Reagan today renewed his call for research on a space-based defense against nuclear missiles, invoking a line from the film ''Star Wars'' to rebut critics of the proposal. ''The Strategic Defense Initiative has been labeled 'Star Wars,' '' Mr. Reagan said in a speech to the National Space Club, ''but it isn't about war, it's about peace. It isn't about retaliation, it's about prevention. It isn't about fear, it's about hope, and in that struggle, if you will pardon my stealing a film line, the force is with us.''
